title: Parliament attacker who tried to kill police and cyclists is jailed for life
text:

A failed accountancy student who tried to kill cyclists and police officers in a suspected terror attack outside the Houses of Parliament has been jailed for at least 15 years.

Salih Khater, 30, deliberately ploughed his Ford Fiesta into a pedestrian and cyclists at a red light before trying to mow down two officers at 30mph on August 14 last year.

He was given a life sentence with a minimum term of 15 years on Monday.

He had a grudge against the Government and prosecutors said it appeared to be a terrorist attack, but Khater, who arrived in Britain in 2010 as a refugee from Sudan, claimed he was lost and it was an accident.

Dramatic CCTV footage showed Khater's car ramming into the commuters in central London before careering into a security lane and crashing into barriers as two officers jumped out of the way.

The Crown Prosecution Service's Counter Terrorism Division, which prosecuted Khater, said it was a "premeditated and deliberate" attack and it was reasonable to assume Khater had a terrorist motive.

The trial at the Old Bailey heard the student, of Birmingham, wanted to cause maximum carnage and it was "miraculous" that no-one was killed.

After two days of deliberation in July, a jury rejected Khater's defence and found him guilty of attempted murder.

(Image: CPS/Twitter)

The court heard how Khater was granted asylum in Britain in 2010 after claiming he had been tortured in his home country.

He had failed his accountancy exams at the University of Coventry and his work as a security guard had dried up.

In the months before the attack, Khater showed signs of "paranoia" about British authorities and emailed Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn to express concern about an "event" involving the intelligence services, the court heard.

(Image: CPS/Twitter)

Khater went to Peterborough and unsuccessfully applied for a fast-track UK passport the day before the incident.

He then set off from Birmingham to London just before 10pm, arriving after midnight.

Evidence from his mobile phone showed he had looked up maps for 10 Downing Street and Westminster on the internet as potential "deliberate targets".

(Image: CPS/Twitter)

CCTV captured Khater arriving in Parliament Square just before 1am and driving around Westminster, checking the layout for the attack five or six hours later.

He then parked up and rested for four-and-a-half hours in Soho before returning to Parliament Square for further reconnaissance.

He went on to do four laps of the square before launching the rush-hour attack, accelerating into cyclists stopped at traffic lights and then crashing into a police barrier at more than 30mph.

(Image: PA)

Pedestrian Paul Brown was crossing the road when Khater's car "came out of nowhere" and hit him, causing bruising and grazes.

Krystof Tokarski and Anya Breen were cycling to work and were waiting at traffic lights when Khater revved his engine and knocked them down.

Mr Tokarski suffered grazes and a broken little finger while Ms Breen was thrown over the bonnet, fracturing her collar bone.

(Image: Getty Images Europe)

Other people were trapped under their bikes, with some screaming in pain.

The defendant made a sharp turn into a slip road, going 32mph, forcing Pc Darren Shotton and Pc Simon Short to dive out of the way.

As armed police removed Khater from the car, the defendant confirmed he was acting alone but failed to explain himself.

(Image: Facebook)

But he claimed it was an accident and he had travelled to London to find the Sudanese embassy to get a visa, but "got lost" around Westminster and panicked.

Giving evidence, Khater said he wanted to return to Sudan to visit his sick mother and had Googled Downing Street and Westminster in his bid to find his way around central London.

He said: "I remember something made me panic. The car was not in my full control at the time."

The incident in August 2018 appeared to be the second terrorist attack at parliament in under 18 months.

In March 2017, terrorist Khalid Masood, 52, mowed down and killed four pedestrians - Aysha Frade, 44, Leslie Rhodes, 75, Kurt Cochran, 54, and Andreea Cristea, 31 - on Westminster Bridge and stabbed unarmed Pc Keith Palmer to death in the grounds of Parliament before being shot dead.
description: Salih Khater, 30, deliberately ploughed his car into a pedestrian and cyclists before trying to mow down two officers at 30mph in a suspected terror attack outside Parliament in central London
